title: Insurance CEO Defends Paid-Leave Program
sub_head: A public option won’t replace private offerings.
body:
In “The Government Family Plan” (Sept. 21), the editorial board cites a survey that found two-thirds of workers who took family or medical leave over the previous two years received some pay. Often, that’s only for a small period of time—and what about the one-third of workers who received no pay at all? We need to ensure all Americans have a safety net that provides paid leave so they can recover from illness or injury, bond with a new child or care for a sick loved one.
The editorial suggests that employers will steer clear of private paid leave if they have the public option. This is not the case. The Ways and Means Committee’s proposal creates a private-public partnership that provides basic coverage to everyone and gives employers the choice to leverage the government program or build a private plan, based on their needs and ability to do more. We see many of our clients choosing to offer richer benefits, even when a state paid leave program is in place. In the war for talent, robust benefits are a key tool in recruitment and retention.
